name: Texas Muslim Womens Foundation Inc
mission: Founded in 2005, Texas Muslim Women's Foundation (TMWF) aims to empower, promote and support all women and their families, with a special focus on North Texas. We are an equal opportunity provider. We engage all members of the community – women, men, seniors, families and youth through our various programs. We provide social and family violence services that foster peace and well-being in the home through our Peace in the Home Services and Peaceful Oasis Shelter. In addition, TMWF also arranges leadership skills development for Muslim youth to inspire the next generation to build a promising future for our society and educational programs for Muslim and non-Muslim community members to learn about topics essential to individual and community welfare.
theoryOfChange: A strategic and holistic approach combining immediate crisis intervention (shelters) with long-term stability (transitional housing, senior home) and economic empowerment (Food 4 Good) to break the cycle of violence.
zakatClaimEvidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://www.tmwf.org/ways-to-give (Source: https://www.tmwf.org/ways-to-give)

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a moderate overall score due to its high financial efficiency and strong alignment with humanitarian causes, though its impact score is tempered by a lack of specific cost-per-beneficiary data.
areas_for_improvement: Enhance data transparency to improve the medium data confidence level of 0.6.
Expand impact reporting to provide more granular cost-per-beneficiary metrics for all programs.

dimension_explanations.alignment: The foundation shows high alignment (41/50) for Muslim donors due to its zakat-eligible status and focus on urgent humanitarian needs like domestic violence support [2][8]. Its mission to serve both the Muslim community and the broader public establishes a strong track record of inclusive social service [3][5].
dimension_explanations.impact: TMWF demonstrates direct provision of services, including housing survivors in shelters and providing rapid re-housing [4][6]. While the organization maintains a high Charity Navigator score of 98.66666666666667/100 and a healthy 3.7 months of working capital, the impact score of 24/50 reflects a need for more detailed evidence regarding the long-term cost-effectiveness of its interventions [1][3].

baseline_narrative.headline: Texas Muslim Women's Foundation provides comprehensive social services and domestic violence support to empower women and families in North Texas.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 86.0%, ensuring the vast majority of funds directly support community services.
Exceptional fundraising efficiency, spending only $0.03 to raise every $1 in revenue.
Strong financial health and accountability with a Charity Navigator score of 98.66666666666667/100.
baseline_narrative.summary: The Texas Muslim Women's Foundation (TMWF) offers a range of programs including emergency shelter, transitional housing, and youth leadership development to improve well-being within and beyond the Muslim community [3][6]. The organization is recognized as zakat-eligible, allowing donors to fulfill their religious obligations through contributions to its social service initiatives [2][8].

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a moderate overall score due to its high financial efficiency and strong alignment with humanitarian causes, though its impact score is tempered by a lack of specific cost-per-beneficiary data.

areas_for_improvement.context: The organization currently has a <cite id="17">board size of only 2 members</cite>, which presents a risk to long-term oversight and institutional stability.
While program ratios are high, the foundation lacks <cite id="18">verified external evaluations or long-term outcome tracking</cite> to prove the efficacy of its interventions.

bbb_assessment.summary: BBB assessment data is not currently available for this organization.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization maintains high financial transparency and a clear theory of change, which partially mitigates governance concerns.
case_against.summary: The primary concern is the <cite id="30">critically small board size</cite> and the absence of <cite id="31">rigorous external impact evaluations</cite>.

confidence.notes: Strong financial transparency but governance and outcome tracking are areas of concern.

alignment.explanation: The organization is a high-fit for Muslim donors, offering <cite id="27">verified zakat eligibility</cite> and serving <cite id="28">underserved populations in North Texas</cite>.
alignment.improvement: Alignment is already strong, but could be enhanced by <cite id="29">expanding services to additional underserved regions</cite> with limited nonprofit coverage.

credibility.explanation: Donors can trust the financial integrity of TMWF due to its <cite id="21">98.66666666666667 Charity Navigator rating</cite> and <cite id="22">100% independent board members</cite>.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the foundation should <cite id="23">expand its board of directors</cite> beyond the current two members to meet standard governance benchmarks.

impact.explanation: Impact is driven by a <cite id="24">86.0% program expense ratio</cite> and a direct provision model that <cite id="25">housed 186 survivors in 2023</cite>.
impact.improvement: The foundation could improve its impact score by <cite id="26">tracking and reporting cost-per-beneficiary metrics</cite> and seeking external evaluations.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade C - Internal tracking of beneficiary counts

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Direct service provision rather than grantmaking

rich_narrative.headline: Texas Muslim Women's Foundation provides comprehensive social services and domestic violence support to empower women and families in North Texas.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who want to support domestic violence survivors and social services within a culturally sensitive, zakat-eligible framework in the United States.
donor_motivations: Want to fulfill zakat obligations through local social services
Care about empowering Muslim women and families in crisis
Value high financial efficiency and low fundraising costs
Prefer supporting established local institutions with a 20-year track record
giving_considerations: Donations support direct provision like shelters and housing
The organization is highly efficient but faces governance risks due to a small board
Impact is measured by output (people served) rather than long-term longitudinal studies
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking international relief or those who require rigorous RCT-level evidence of long-term social outcomes.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects consistent tracking of beneficiary numbers (outputs) but a lack of independent external evaluations (outcomes).
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: TMWF uses a direct provision model to move survivors from crisis (emergency shelter) to stability (transitional housing) while providing social support to prevent future vulnerability.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that shelter and housing programs effectively break the cycle of violence for survivors.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: With a 17.3% growth rate and expanding shelter needs in North Texas, the organization has significant capacity to absorb more funding.

organizational_capacity.geographic_reach: North Texas (Dallas, Collin, Denton, Tarrant, Rockwall counties)

peer_comparison.differentiator: TMWF stands out for its <cite id="34">$0.03 fundraising efficiency</cite>, which is significantly better than many peers in the humanitarian space.

strengths.detail: The foundation spends only <cite id="10">$0.03 to raise every $1 in revenue</cite>, ensuring minimal leakage of donor funds to administrative overhead.
TMWF maintains <cite id="11">3.7 months of working capital in working capital</cite>, providing a stable buffer for its critical shelter operations.
The organization directs <cite id="12">86.0% of its expenses toward programs</cite>, significantly exceeding the industry standard of 75%.

strengths_deep_dive: TMWF's operational excellence is evidenced by its <cite id="13">perfect 100/100 scores in Culture and Leadership</cite> from Charity Navigator. This internal stability supports a robust direct-provision model that served <cite id="14">137 emergency shelter residents</cite> and <cite id="15">216 non-residential domestic violence clients</cite> according to 2024 reporting. The organization's ability to scale is reflected in its revenue growth from <cite id="16">$3.39 million in 2021 to over $4.66 million in 2023</cite>.
rich_narrative.summary: Founded in <cite id="1">2005</cite>, the Texas Muslim Women's Foundation (TMWF) provides a comprehensive safety net for women and families in North Texas, specifically addressing domestic violence and social service needs. The organization operates with a <cite id="2">98.66666666666667/100 overall score from Charity Navigator</cite>, reflecting high standards of accountability. TMWF's impact is centered on direct service provision, including <cite id="3">emergency shelter for 186 survivors</cite> and supporting <cite id="4">204 individuals in transitional or rapid re-housing</cite> during the 2023 fiscal year. Beyond crisis intervention, the foundation offers <cite id="5">social services, senior programs, and youth leadership development</cite> to foster long-term community well-being. Financially, the organization demonstrated significant growth with a <cite id="6">3-year revenue CAGR of 17.3%</cite>, reaching <cite id="7">total revenue of $4,665,216</cite> in 2023. As a <cite id="8">zakat-eligible organization</cite>, it provides a vital channel for Muslim donors to support vulnerable populations including the <cite id="9">poor (fuqara), needy (masakin), and those in debt (gharimin)</cite> within a culturally sensitive framework.
